bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 19, 1947

div1.p: Hench is delighted to receive letters from yellow fever collaborators. Lazear's daughter shows interest in Hench's research.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 19, 1947
div1.opener:
March 19, 1947
General Jefferson R. Kean
2804 N Street, North West
Georgetown
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I am not sure that I ever answered your kind letter of 27
January with the most interesting enclosures. I am delighted to have
them and the letters of Doctor Finlay, Doctor Guiteras, and others.
These are all most interesting.

I am especially happy to hear of Colonel Siler's continued
recovery. I just heard from him. By now he has probably sent you
the remarks I made at the Meeting of the Walter Reed Memorial Association.

Apropos of the material that you have so kindly given me
and other material, may I say that Lazear's daughter, Peggy, is at last
becoming interested. Of course, she never met me and probably had sus-
picions about my motives but recently she sent me a very interesting
booklet which I did not have and told me that she had her father's
microscope and was contemplating lending it to me--permanently I hope.
Houston and I have been trying to locate it in some hospital in Santa
Barbara to which Houston thought his mother had given it. He didn't
know that Peggy had it. Recently, therefore, I wrote her a long letter
telling her how I became interested in this subject, telling her fully
my purposes in making the collection, and telling her that I regarded
myself merely as a custodian to a collection that will be made avail-
able to all students. She seems really interested now.

Next week I have my course here (Members of the American
College of Physicians) and the following week I go to Portland to give
three Sommer Foundation lectures and then to Denver to give four lectures.
I won't be back for about three weeks.

Recently General Truby returned to me some wonderful answers
to a voluminous questionnaire I sent him. He wants me to let you see
a copy--which I will do as soon as I catch my breath, but probably not
until I return from the west.
div1.closer: Always sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alp
